reviewText:
I've never experienced another MMO with this many bugs.

First, in order to log in with  Steam there is a separate launcher from the game. This only works half the time and there is no way to manually log in. After every update it stops working or sometimes it just stops working for no apparent reason. Second, quests are bugged. I've had a main storyline quest just break with no way to recover it and no other quests available, effectively making the entire character useless. Google revealed that there are several quests in particular that have been broken for years without anyone working on them. Third, the prices for items are different depending if you are on the Warp Portal website or if you're on Steam. The best deals are on their site. Also, some items expire after a couple of days (which is bad if you can't log in half of the time.)

The game has been doctored so that Warp Portal can make more money. In the original Korean servers, there are quite a few Tiger mounts that you could purchase for in game money. All of these have been removed and put in a cash shop were you have a CHANCE at getting them permamently in a box. (There is only one mount available that does not require real money.) Costumes are not permament either. Most costumes expire after 30 days and you need to buy extenders to keep it. Both these items cost real money. If you want a permament costume the only way to get it is by more chance items, or by getting a lot of rare stones to play a pyramid game (which has an extrememly low chance of getting an item.) Inventory / Bank space is severely limited. Only 'medium' bags are dropped / purchasable which hardly have any slots. You will get these at level 10. If you want actual space, you need to buy bags from the cash shop. RO2 may not be a 'pay to win' but it sure is a 'pay to do anything fun' sort of game. Server population is pretty low. No one seems to be socializing. In fact, all the social interaction I had was a creepy guy hitting on me. So, if you play MMOs in hopes of finding some new buddies to talk too, you won't find them here.

If you insist on plaything this game, do not do it through Steam. Go to the site itself, or better yet find another company / private server. Warp portal is not doing a good job integrating RO2 with Steam. If the game actually worked as intended I might suggest it for someone looking for a casual game to play with friends (if you don't mind old school rpg grinding) but since Warp portal provides such a terrible service, I suggest trying one of Aeria Games' anime MMOs instead. They have a cash shop too, but they are more fair about what they give you.

Overall RO2 is a HUGE DISSAPOINTMENT and I am not saying this because it is different from the first game. I am saying this because of the bugs, Warp portal's poor choice of business model and all the issues I've been having. I've played a ton of f2p mmos and none have quite been this bad. You have been warned!

This game brings shame to the original Ragnarok, which gave many of us MMORPGers our very first taste of what it is to play an MMORPG. Comparisons aside, Ragnarok Online 2 is still one bad game. Stay away from it.

RO2 is ridden with a horrible pay2win system; bugs that never or take hell of a long time to get fixed; unbalanced classes; a ridiculous amount of grinding to earn enough money to catch up with those who can buy from the cash shop; and endgame content that is almost impossible to get through unless you use glitches. The staff regularly release new content and events but leave a lot of the game's problems to the side. If you check their Facebook page, people still complain about bugs and other problems with the game all the time.

The community is also pretty toxic since there are a lot of immature players who are super competitive about the silliest things, including sitting space in town. The only reason I stayed for as long as I did was because I had an awesome guild and really good friends who still played, so I was able to do endgame dungeons with a decent party. But when a majority of them moved to other MMOs, there was nothing left to do but leave as well.

Just... stay away.

reviewText:
I can't, in all honesty, recommend this game. Although the early game aspect is fun and exciting, that facade quickly slips. Despite easy and quick leveling in early game, late game content is still severely lacking, and heavily unbalanced. Constant gamebreaking bugs, pay-to-win events, poor server optimization, lag and latency issues, incredible graphical defects and compatibility issues with regional settings on your computer make the game nigh unplayable at times, especially after big patches.

The Pay-to-win model breaks balance between free to play players and paying players, and the gap between them is offputting to say the least.

The biggest problem I have with the game is the ridiculous amount of RNG uses in places where there shouldn't have to be random attribution. Random chances to get an item that once opened up, gives a random chance for an item, and combines with other items with a random chance to get a good item. So many recursive random chances that player advancement is purely luck based, rather than progression based on player activity is unbearable to say the least.

There are many good things about the game, but honestly, it's hard to talk about them, when the first thing you think of after a long session of raiding dungeons or grinding was: that was pointless.

One of the most disappointing games I have ever played. The most unprofessional game management I have ever seen. The only reason I could see anyone giving this game a shot is for nostalgia's sake and even that isn't worth the headache. There's hardly any semblance to RO1 other than a few mobs/cities. The actual mechanics and gameplay are completely different.

You might be lulled into the game starting out but once you hit level 50, you get slapped by the AoV update which changed the game from a quest based/storyline progression focused on dungeon raiding to a full grind progression with only daily repeated quests and few true raids. I find the beginning levels to be extremely misleading now, as the game completely switches focus once you hit the level 50 cap. If you make it that far, then you run into the issues in the rest of my review.

The game constantly suffers from bugs, glitches, and exploits. You can expect every content patch to come with atleast the same amount, if not more, bugs. You can expect these bugs to be fixed in the next 5 months.... maybe. I actually quit, only to come back and see that it STILL suffers from the same issues. WP/Gravity continue to release patches that do nothing but break more aspects of the game. Meanwhile it takes months to get any bugs fixed.

Examples:
Woe update- invisible bridges for over a month, texture glitches, guild cape fiasco
Pet update- immobilize bosses, gm dna handout, hacked pets lvl 4(near impossible to get)
AoV update- imbalanced all classes, pvp broken, sp consumption abnormally high still
SEA Merger- brought over op items, bound items could be unbound stacking with newly obtained items, bound seeds could be sold by rune removing, costumes with unobtainable stats, hacked lvl 4 full pet inventory, guild/char name conflicts glitching people's accounts/chars
Card refine hack- massive influx in duped/hacked +9 refined cards, some still exist
Thai Merger- broken zeny conversion%, freyja economy destroyed
Jawaii update- storyline quests broken, job change quest broken, quest glitches

I don't think they even play their own game. That or they have no idea what they broke or how to fix it so they throw attempts at a fix at it, and hope something sticks.

If you like button-mash, endless grind boredom with random periods of glitched/broken/bugged class/skill/environment mechanics, you will like RO2, as that is what it has become sadly.



TL;DR: If you're looking for a Ragnarok sequel, just wait for Tree of Savior.

reviewText:
I havent played the game long, however I can already see why I personally will not be playing long just looking at the 'temp' items in the cash shop.

1. Card System

I actually like this part, I'm a person who loves completing collection and like it even more if those collections have a point to them. Each card has a set of stats on them that boost your character, and you can have up to 5 cards at a time (You unlock up to 5 slots as you level). You can also upgrade the cards to be more powerful, though this is more luck than anything eles. It takes 5 diffrent cards to give it a go, however if you fail you lose ALL those cards, so if you have been farming a monster for hours to get that one card you wanted and you fail upgrading it, well...sorry.

Storing of the cards is also probomatic at best, unless you pay for the card album, your patheticly small bags will overflow with these and other junk you need for quests and crafting. Now paying for the card album itself wouldent be bad except you only get that storage for 30 days at a time, after which you have to pay more real world money to keep it open.

2. Storage: this brings us to one of my pet peeves for any f2p mmo, having to constantly buy storage. You will never have enough space, and they know it. want a 30 slot bag just so you can haul that crap around? better bust open the wallet. Expand your bank a little? Swipe the card sir! In a perfect world, this stuff would be managed with in game currancy, not real world money.

3. Comunity: I know that gold spammers are the bane of any mmo, however they are not even present here, which should be a good thing until you see the chat. Some of the most annoying chatter i have seen. The chat channels are not even regulated. The filter also does more harm than good, bleeping out half of every 4 or so words it 'thinks' are swear words. So while I do not see gold sellers spaming in the game, I know its not moderation, its just they think the game will tank apperently.

There are a few things that are good in this game, and from time to time i run into people who are willing to help a newbie out instead of just spouting off some insults just because i asked a question. So while I did press 'not recomended' let me just add this....Its worth playing if you have nothing to do, just do not spend any money on it because later on down the road you  will regret it.

reviewText: Ragnarok Online 2, the fifth installment in Nintendo's Online 2 series, is a story-based third person action adventure game. Dropping the player into the midst of an epic battle for control of Middle-earth right from the start, Ragnarok focuses on delivering an individualised single-player experience comparable to that of the Dragon Age series. The player meets his/her love interest, the knight Hans Rapad, early on before he is taken prisoner by an evil sorceror and trapped in an ancient castle ruin. Without spoiling anything, the second act of the game focuses on Hans' rescue, and as an avid Hammerwatch player I know that other fans of that franchise will feel very at home here. As with previous Online 2 games, abilities and combat strength is determined by a vast, inclusive skill tree--think Path of Exile, but without an initial choice of class at the beginning of play. Instead, the main character and all unlockable party members (each available for purchase in-game for $3.99) each start with a simple choice of Focus (Strength, Dexterity, Intelligence, Wisdom, Constitution, Speed,  Charisma, Presence, Corruption, Agility, Fertility) and build outward on the skill tree from there. This makes play highly customizable, and gives huge replay value to the game. Combat is similar to that found in the „Åã„Åü„Çè Â∞ëÂ•≥ series, with fast-paced and innovative combos being the bread-and-butter. The unique combo system allows players to create their own combos, offering even more customization and crazy action possibilities. Overall, I would rate this game a 7.76 out of 10; while it offers a lot of options, great gameplay, an amazing story, and awesome replayablity, purchasing additional party members forces the monsters to scale their difficulty, which means one cannot simply pay real money to succeed at the game more easily. I'm looking forward to Nintendo adding that feature in the next Online 2 installment. Here's hoping!

reviewText:
I had high hopes for this game.

I'm not much for any MMO but the original Ragnarok was a lite hearted and fun game with a great comunity of people and lots of creative astetic and functional customisations.

While technically those mechanics are in this incarnation, this game does not use them propperly to get a cohesive feel to them.
the voiceovers at (least for the english) are HORIBLE, probably the worst use of voice and animation I have seen in a long time.
with the choice of font color your eyes are drawn to the summery for a quest and not the plot dialogue that would motivate the character in world. For me it was so distracting that I on more than one occasion was scratching my head and had to go back and read the dialogue again.
some of the quests are simply find a character, then that starts another quest where you have to talk to that same person again.
Early on there is a time where you meet the person then have to talk to them four times, this could have been swayed by just haveing an actual dialogue with the person.
When you meet the king you are given the offer to become an apprentice knight.
then it actually says that your character says yes. removing your choice.

In a medium founded on naritive (JRPG) and a style founded on choice and player empowerment (3D quest based games) this fails at both.

I love the look and feel of the Ragnarok world. (Poorings are just to cute to ignore) but without a solid story to add richness to the world and more consideration given to the NPCs and the PC choices this one is going to likely be forgotten fast.

However I am considering reinstalling the original Ragnarok to get my pooring fix in a fun and lite hearted world. Just because it's 3D and looks nice does nto mean it is better.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Mediocre MMO, but the nostalgia's still nice for those who played R√ñ1. Better with friends, boring alone.

As a MMO, R√ñ2 is below average, quality-wise. Some might chalk it up by saying it's Free2Play, but I've played better F2P MMOs before; R√ñ2 gives an aftertaste of unfinished game, a Forever Beta whose developpers bit more than they could chew. The character design isn't particularly original, and the voices are standard. The graphics are okay at first, but get rather dull after the tenth hour. However sometimes you will stumble upon a beautiful scenery (and sometimes, stumble through), but it's not often enough to make it acceptable. The gameplay is entirely standard; the good thing is that you won't be lost with the controls, but if you were looking for something original/different: look somewhere else. As for the story, it isn't grandiose, but if you played the first game, you might like some elements of it.

One big issue in the game, that I hinted at earlier, is how buggy it is, and how little the GM support is. In all the time I played, I managed to contact a GM only once, and managed to get stuck in [trees, houses, mountains, invisible rocks, broken stairs, dunes, out of bound, water, wall, boat, ...] more times than I can count. In one occurence, I got stuck in a mountain; when trying to use a move skill to get out, I warped through the map, fell under it and stayed stuck. When I logged out and back in, I was 3 zones ahead, monsters were 10+ levels above me. Another time, I simply swum my way out of the map, then fell again; same scenario. Although it was hilarious when it was discovered, this kind of bug quickly grew annoying.

That being said, if you've played R√ñ1 before, and have some friends who did too, you might want to give it a try; despite everything, it's still fun to play it with friends, even if only halfway through.

There is a long list of things wrong with this game for me to tell you straight up that it is not worth downloading/playing this game from the start.

First of all, this game is pay2win, as there is a VIP item in their cash shop that gives +10 to all stats and something like 20% movement speed bonus.  This item is not permanent, and the shop seems to only currently sell it at one week increments.

Second of all, this game is bound to your steam account, so that means that if you were playing this before the steam version came out, or were unlucky to begin playing on the first day, you can't actually run this game through steam.

Third of all, this game plays like a generic MMO where your main source of experience is fetch quests, so either find x person or gather x items, as this game has level barriers, which means that if you encounter enemies 5 levels above you, it basically means it won't be worth trying to kill them as they will probably one-shot you or you will not deal enough damage to make the experience worth it.

Fourth of all, the steam cash shop is actually more expensive than if you were playing through the original game client.  This is because they made it so that steam users are bound through their steam account, so the cash shop transactions go through steam, and I guess steam wanted a cut of the profits or else this game wouldn't have gotten onto steam.

Fifth of all, the endgame of this game is only raiding with people.  This might not be a downside to a lot of people, but if you check youtube for any videos of raids in this game, it looks horrific with the horrible camera controls and boring combat.  There actually is zero reason to play this game, as there are better free MMO's out there such as Neverwinter or Path of Exile.

The final complaint that I have about this game is probably centric to only me, as other people seem to get by fine.  I cannot use mumble with this game, as it locks my voice in-place as soon as it launches, so if my mic is held down when the game launches, it will be stuck to the on" position until I alt-tab and repress my push-to-talk key. reviewText: Never played the first Ragnarok but I've played the phone version of the first one. And i can honestly say that I really like the graphics/game play of the first one (if the phone one is anything close to the actual first Ragnarok). Ragnarok Online 2 is a game that I personally enjoyed and from the first night of playing it me and my friend got to lvl 10. Now being the huge MMORPG fan that I am and like any MMO, Ragnarok 2 has some faults that any MMO will have. One of the biggest faults of RO2 is the grind between levels and the amount of exp that some quests will give you. In the early levels of RO2 you don't really realize the grind since it's not hard to level up a new character from.. lets say 1-10, then 10-15 and then 15-20. The leveling system is all good until you get to lvl 20 and then try and get to lvl 25 so that u can learn your claases new job (mine being thief going to rogue). With knowing that you can learn a new job soon and get some new moves, you get all pumped and go the hardest you can to lvl quickly. This is where you quickly notice the change in the exp rate and how much exp you need to actually lvl.....This is where the grinding starts to really get annoying.\n\nIf Gravity fixed the leveling system past level 20, it would make the game a whole lot more fun and make it feel less than a chore. Over all I would recommend this game since it has bought me and countless friends that I have already recommended this game to hours of fun! My advice for this game is to make sure that you have a friend with you when you get to lvl 20, so you don't have to get bored out of your mind when trying to lvl!

reviewText:
To me, instead of making a Legitimate upgrade to RO they made yet another basic MMO.

In RO1 I could enjoy the skills, their animations and my overall time played because it felt alright. Here in RO2, it feels like a poorly made clone MMO. Animations cut themselves off or repeat suddenly. Sound effects are insanely annoying due to the sheer amount of enemies that repeat their stupid sound effect over and over again. The UI is entirely made to look cutsy and just cludders up the screen with useless crap. (Yeah, I get they love the poro but give it a rest already!)

The camera movement starts off stupidly fast for some reason, as if this is some fast pace FPS or Third Person Action game. It's far from needed as you'll just walk to target, smack target and then walk to next target. In short, it doesn't feel right. The game is played without issue on my computer but the actual gameplay is not smooth. It feels janky and unfinished; basically lacking quality polish. Then it bombards you with Cash shop stuff and tries to ease you into all their related items and options. It's content first then ask us to buy your crap, not the other way around.

I'm sure the game has all the End level nonsense as RO1 did or jobs within jobs of jobs but I couldn't be arsed to play the game any longer than I did. It litterally brings nothing interesting or new to the table. It takes from existing games and doesn't take the really good parts from them.

I want to enjoy the combat, I really do but if I wanted to play an extremely slow paced MMO there is still RO1 or a list of many other similar games.

If you aren't really wanting to play this game then just don't waste your time downloading the game and then having to patch it afterwards as the game obviously doesn't send patches to steam to download. Play something else.

reviewText: I've never been one for MMORPG's. I've tried a couple but none of them seem to pull me in very far and I get bored and leave in the first couple hours. But this game is one amazing exception. The artstyle and look of the game is beautiful, so colourful and detailed. The voice acting is really good as each character and NPC has a voice rather than just a silent protagonist. Gameplay is as you would imagine it to be with an MMORPG with you levelling up and buying new skills with your points. This game has some nice additions, my favourite being the 'Card' system. When you kill and enemy there is a chance he will drop a card, this card then can be equipped and add special bonus stats to you character. That one thing alone makes me want to go out and fight as many monsters as I can and believe me there are many, all of which looks beautiful and unique. The story is well crafted and I've managed to stay with it with no confusion at all. For a free to play, you should definately get it and play with friends. It get's a lot better when you create a party and devise your strategies together which become incredibly effective.\n10/10

reviewText:
As a note, this is my first time reviewing a game, so if it sucks.... Bite me ^^

Ragnarok online 2 I picked up by accident, clicking it while trying to get rid of an ad, and then downloading it out of curiosity. I am quite pleased I did.

The game itself is (from my limited experience), reminiscent of the playstyle of early WoW. Focused on the usual core classes and the first person MMO style I very much enjoy. The core classes are pretty varied, with option to diversify into two subsets when you get to a higher level.

Atop the core classes there is a Job system which is while second to your class, has its own leveling system and, through proper use of the job system will allow you to level much quicker. Simply put, you can make your own armor and weapons, make your own potions, or buff yourself even as a fighter before a match, depending on the job you pick.

The game is Free to play, so I would say it is at least worth a brief look at if nothing else. (As a note, the graphics start of fairly high end, nearly crippling my laptop on my first go. I would advise reducing the render distance to 2-3 to make sure it wont interfere with gameplay).

I would say that the game greatly benefits from having friends to play with, but it can be a fairly enjoyable solo adventure, with a surprisingly interesting story. I expected a simplistic, insulting reason to just go and murder several areas of color swapped creatures. Instead I got a large variety of creatures, many different NPC's and points of view. While not perfect there has been honest effort to make an interesting and involved story in which you participate, including an earlier section whereupon you end up fighting your own repressed memories.

I certainly would rate this worth a try, and possibly to keep.

7.5/10

Having played this game now for a good length after American launch, I can say that things are SLOWLY improving.  Is it a worthy successor of the original RO?  Some ways: yes, others: no.  The graphic style translated very nicely over to 3D and the game definitely has the Original's feel.

What is missing, however, is the level of accesorizing, number of jobs and even number of skills available to classes. My #1 gripe remains the 'support' given to the game.  Warp Portal, the service used as launcher and forums/tech support system is unfriendly to use and hard to locate what you need.  If you make an error filling out a form, they don't tell you what is wrong.  When you ask for password recovery, you're still waiting on the promised email hours later.  GMs are still aloof with no way to contact one.

To thier credit, they did manage to fix the chat issues.

Overall, I say play the game. If you like it, you'll love it.  But pray you never get technical difficulties!

reviewText: Having a rather biased opinion of what I wanted/expected from this game due to having played it's prequel for years, I must say i was rather shocked.  At first I thought it was just a crappy Korean Cash Shop WoW clone with Ragnarok imagery, but was i quite wrong. Quest based leveling without the grind is a nice plus, not to mention the PvP that is alot of fun to participate in.  The cash shop is not a requirement to compete/enjoy the game, but is there for those who want it.  VIP is only 9 bucks a month, and worth every penny as well.  It's enjoyable without putting a penny of real world money into it, and even more fun if you do.  All in all, RO2 is not as cheesy and crappy as it appears, and the endgame content for gear is also pretty fun for what it is.  Give it a shot.  The community is nice, helpful, welcoming, and much like the previous game MAKES this title worth playing for hours on end.

reviewText: Having a rather biased opinion of what I wanted/expected from this game due to having played it's prequel for years, I must say i was rather shocked.  At first I thought it was just a crappy Korean Cash Shop WoW clone with Ragnarok imagery, but was i quite wrong.  It DOES feature some of these things, but does so with a style and flair that was quite unexpected.  At first you will think otherwise, but after a few hours of leveling and exploration you soon learn that this is a whole other beast.  Quest based leveling without the grind is a nice plus, not to mention the PvP that is alot of fun to participate in.  The cash shop is not a requirement to compete/enjoy the game, but is there for those who want it.  VIP is only 9 bucks a month, and worth every penny as well.  It's enjoyable without putting a penny of real world money into it, and even more fun if you do.  All in all, RO2 is not as cheesy and crappy as it appears, and the endgame content for gear is also pretty fun for what it is.  Give it a shot.  The community is nice, helpful, welcoming, and much like the previous game MAKES this title worth playing for hours on end.
